awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Analysis of Nematic Liquid Crystals and L-infinity Variational Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The problems to be solved in this project are not only very challenging mathematically but also have strong connections and profound applications to other fields such as fluid mechanics and complex fluids, applied physics and material sciences, and control engineering.  Rigorous analysis of both the existence and the smoothness of certain kinds solutions to our models can predict the formation of singularities, allow researchers to gain insights into the turbulence phenomena, and justify both computational and experimental studies made by applied scientists and engineers. The proposed problems in the project will also serve as tools to train graduate students, and constitute as main parts of future research monographs aimed at both advanced graduate students and researchers.

The technical side of this project is to study analytic issues in the three parts: (i) the hydrodynamic flow of nematic liquid crystals, (ii) variational problems on both liquid crystal droplets and the isotropic-nematic phase transitions in liquid crystals, and (iii) the L-infinity variational problems. The first part  deals with the Ericksen-Leslie system modeling the hydrodynamics of nematic liquid crystals, which is a strongly nonlinear-coupled system between the incompressible Navier-Stokes equation of the underlying fluid velocity field and the transported heat flow of harmonic maps for the orientation director field of the nematic liquid crystal molecules. The objective is to establish existence and partial regularity for Leray-Hopf type weak solutions in dimension three for arbitrary large initial data. The second part investigates both existence and classification of possible optimal configuration in the liquid crystal droplets and the formation of sharp interface between the isotropic and nematic phases by employing the Ericksen's model of variable degree of orientations for uniaxial nematic liquid crystals. The third part is to study the uniqueness of Aronsson's equations or absolute minimizers of L-infinity functionals that involve Hamiltonian functions with spatial dependence, the regularity of viscosity solutions to general Aronsson's equations,  and the Liouville property of infinity harmonic functions in any dimension. 

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI has investigated the analytic issues arising from the following research themes: 

 The first one is on both vectorial and tensorial models on the hydrodynamic motions of nematic liquid crystal materials proposed by Ericksen and Leslie using Oseen-Frank's vectorial approach, and Beris-Edwards using Landau- de Gennes' Q-tensor approach. The specific goals of this project are establishing the global existence of finite energy weak solutions and their partial regularities and the uniqueness/non-uniqueness. In this context, the PI have achieved several partial answers to these fundamental and challenging questions, including the construction of finite time singularity in dimension two for simplified Ericksen-Leslie system,  the existence of partially smooth suitable weak solutions to the co-rotational Beris-Edwards Q-tensor system (with either de Gennes potential or Ball-Majumdar singular potential) in dimension three,  the partial regularity of Ericken modified model with kinematic transport effects, and the sharp interface asymptotic analysis in the isotropic-nematic liquid crystal phase transitions, among other results.

The second one is on the Aronsson equation arising in the L-infinity type variational problem, which is closely connected with the field of optimal controls. The specific aims of this project are focused on the uniqueness/non-uniquenessand differentiability and C1-regularity of viscosity solution to Aronsson's equation or absolute minimizers associated with general Hamiltonian functions. In this context, the PI has shown everywhere differentiability of viscosity solution to a class of Aronsson equation in which the Hamiltonian is a Riemannian metric type; and uniqueness of absolute minimizer for strictly convex Hamiltonian H(x,p);  and optimal condition on H(p) ensuring the C1-regularity in dimension two.

As by-products, the PI has also obtained results in heat flow of harmonic maps and half-harmonic maps, the stochastic Ericksen-Leslie system, the Cosserat micropolar elasticity problem, and the Navier-Stokes-Planck-Nernst-Poisson system. This project has led to 19 research article published in quality mathematical journals. It has partially supported the PI to train and graduate three PhD students during this period of support (two of them have worked as postdocs in Universities and another one has worked in the financial industry). The PI has also mentored a postdoc who collaborated on this project.

The PI has given numerous invited lectures in seminar and conferences to disseminate the research findings resulted from this NSF supported project.
